description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Whats this? A theme on a Friday? This must be The Timess karmic balance to this past Sundays themeless tour de force by Brooke Husic and Will Nediger. And as themes go, this one, in a debut by Robert Logan, is so subtle that you could be forgiven for not noticing it at all.

title: Review: A Faithful Kinky Boots, With All Its Pizazz and Pitfalls
description: You cant keep a drag queen down, at least not for long. It was only April 2019 that the Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein musical Kinky Boots closed on Broadway after a six-year run, and already its back in town. The Britain-set show, in which the statuesque performer Lola saves a provincial shoe factory by inspiring a line of toweringly outr footwear, is now running Off Broadway.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: ACROSTIC  This unconventional excerpt took me a while to piece together. Just as I was getting frustrated, I learned that its focus was as plain as a prominent feature on ones face. So was the focus of its source, a 2003 book by Gabrielle Glaser called The Nose: A Profile of Sex, Beauty and Survival. I found this funny and interesting  the whole nose angle, I mean  and I loved how quickly my mind started coming up with faint scents of freshly mowed grass and zoo animals, among others.

title: From the First Date, Looking the Part of Husband and Wife
description: On their first date, at a Manhattan wine bar in May 2016, a waiter mistakenly referred to Michael Angelo McMillan II as Caroline Benning Hubbards husband.

title: Lockdown Was Our Romantic Bubble, but Bubbles Burst
description: During the two months of lockdown last spring in Shanghai, residents were mostly confined to their homes and hallways. For a single woman like me who, at 29, lives alone and is self-employed, my entire life was reduced to me, myself and I.

title: When a Dating App Didnt Work, an Old-Fashioned Setup Did
description: Shafin Fattahs chance at a relationship with Luvana Chowdhury didnt seem too promising when she never responded after he swiped right on her profile on Muzmatch, a Muslim dating app now called Muzz, in late 2020.

title: At Karaoke and as a Couple, Always in Unison
description: Zohar Hannah Fuller spent about a year inviting Maryse Shaina Pearce to events before Ms. Pearce finally attended one.

title: It Was Magic From the First Second
description: Chelsea White is a whole lot, in the best possible way. She is charming, self-deprecating, engrossing and describes herself on her website as a host-writer-producer-speaker-comedian-cat enthusiast. She developed a weekly Instagram live show, What a Delight! with Chelsea White, that involved a guest, a sidekick in a mask, and a discussion of weekly events that entranced her. She wanted to share it with whomever is willing to listen.

title: Quotation of the Day: Rover, Too, May End Up Struggling with Dementia
description: It turns out that probably the best model for human aging has been aging alongside of us for hundreds and hundreds of years.

title: Corrections: Aug. 26, 2022
description: An article on Aug. 19 about a sculptural billboard on Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood designed by the architect Tom Wiscombe referred to Wiscombe as a professor at Southern California Institute of Architecture in downtown Los Angeles; while he remains a professor there, he has been placed on paid leave. The institute declined to comment on Wiscombes leave, which came after students criticism of internships at his firm.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Vladimir Putin ordered a sharp increase in the size of Russias armed forces yesterday, signaling a lengthy commitment to the war in Ukraine.

title: Retail Marijuana in New York: Where the Goliaths Bolster the Davids
description: Good morning. Its Friday. Well get an update on a new New York industry  retail marijuana. And, in the heat of late August, well look into why subway stations arent air-conditioned.

title: Game Face
description: The perils of early adolescence are often depicted in broad strokes. The Bully. The Crush. The Zit. But in reality these tender years are much more nuanced. Childhood friendships slowly begin to outgrow themselves and change. Cracks begin to emerge in our once-infallible parents, revealing them to be flawed human beings. Questions of self-identity percolate to the surface, demanding answers.

title: Bills in Britain Will Soar 80% as Energy Crisis Crashes Into Europe
description: For months, a tsunami of high energy costs has borne down on Europe. On Friday, the first big waves crashed ashore in Britain, with the news that household gas and electricity bills will nearly double in October.

title: Soldiering On
description: In 1860, there were approximately 35,000 Chinese people in the United States, about 200 of whom lived in the Eastern part of the country. Of these, 50-60 would go on to fight in the American Civil War. Most were Union soldiers, but there were exceptions, like the two eldest sons of the famous conjoined twins Chang and Eng Bunker  Christopher Bunker, the son of Chang, and Stephen Bunker, the son of Eng, who were both enslavers (like their fathers) and Confederate soldiers.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: FRIDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Chinas Record Drought Is Drying Rivers and Feeding Its Coal Habit
description: HONG KONG  Car assembly plants and electronics factories in southwestern China have closed for lack of power. Owners of electric cars are waiting overnight at charging stations to recharge their vehicles. Rivers are so low there that ships can no longer carry supplies.

title: The Long Tail of Covid-19 Disinformation
description: Two shots, three shots, four shots, five  how many shots will you survive?

title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: This week's roundup includes a gut-wrenching biography of Dostoyevskys second wife, a wisecracking history of law-breaking animals and more.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including George Miller's latest film, "3,000 Years of Longing."

title: Trump Golf Course in New York City Will Host Saudi-Backed Event
description: A New York City-owned golf course managed by former President Donald J. Trumps family business is expected to host a Saudi Arabia-backed tournament in October, a city official confirmed on Thursday.

title: Democrats Gamble With Ads That Highlight Far-Right Candidates
description: With the ads, Democrats hope to push out moderate conservatives who may be fiercer competition in November. Critics say the strategy carries risks.

title: Democrats Might Get Exceptionally Lucky This Fall, and They Should Be Ready for That
description: Republicans are still favored to gain seats in the midterm elections but are not as favored as you might have thought.

title: A Nuanced History of the Forces Shaping U.S.-Israel Relations
description: For many decades now, a supposed mystery has lurked at the heart of American foreign policy: Why has the United States supported Israel so staunchly and for so long, especially when doing so seems to come at a high cost in blood, treasure and world opinion?

title: Monkeypox Cases Are Declining in New York City and Globally
description: Monkeypox cases are declining in New York City and globally as more people get vaccinated and as they change their sexual behavior in response to the outbreak, health officials said this week.

title: The Sale of a Product Responsible for Bloodshed and Fear Is Still Tied to Our Wildlife
description: Regardless of whether they hunt, gun buyers have long underwritten efforts to conserve and restore American landscapes for hunting with an excise tax that manufacturers pay on the guns, ammunition and archery equipment they produce. For the 2022 fiscal year alone, this tax generated a record $1.1 billion, nearly all of it from guns and ammo.

title: Webb Telescope Sees a Carbon Dioxide Atmosphere Way Out There
description: The James Webb Space Telescope is having a fantastic rookie season.

title: Maternal Instinct Is a Myth That Men Created
description: Around the time that Mimi Niles became a mother, an upstairs neighbor in her New York City apartment building had twins. When the two women ran into each other in the hallway or on the sidewalk, Ms. Niles would ask the neighbor how she was faring.

title: Foreign Films, English Titles and the Dilemma Distributors Face
description: Two years ago, international film releases in the United States reached a new pinnacle with the crowning of Bong Joon Hos Parasite as best picture at the Academy Awards. But before Parasite or any other non-English-language film even hits theaters, a basic question has to be settled: the title.

title: Donald Trump Is Not Above the Law
description: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

title: In a Sweltering Texas Jail, Cool Towels but No Air-Conditioners
description: EDINBURG, Texas  Rashes from heat are common. Metal furniture is hot to the touch. Hyperthermia and dehydration are a constant risk, mitigated with fans, tepid water and wet towels. Deaths, though rare, have occurred.

title: What Is the Merge?
description: Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform, is set to unveil a new technological infrastructure next month that is designed to reduce its energy consumption by more than 99 percent.

title: How to Tread Lightly in Fragile Places
description: Like the 18 other passengers on the ship Origin, from the expedition cruise company Ecoventura, I went to the Galpagos Islands in May to be awed by nature. Swimming with barrel-rolling sea lions, seeing a blue-footed booby chick peeking out from beneath its mother, kayaking with flamingoes and experiencing the meditative pace of a giant tortoise  all exceeded the goal.

title: The Seeds Strike Back
description: Chia seeds are making a comeback  again.

title: A Social Media Star of a Changed Middle East: An Arab From Israel in Dubai
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  All along the Dubai waterfront, Nuseir Yassin kept bumping into fans. An Egyptian tourist asked for a photograph. A yacht club manager from Zimbabwe stopped for a chat. A group of Filipinos gasped and called after him.

title: Can Coco Gauff the Tennis Prodigy Become a Tennis Legend?
description: When Coco Gauff arrived in Paris in May for the French Open, she did not expect the tournament to be a milestone in her tennis career. It had already been a tough season: At its start, she flew across the globe to Australia, training and competing for four weeks, only to lose in the first round of the Australian Open. Not long before the French Open, she lost in the first round of a tournament on clay, the surface she would be playing on in Paris. Those kinds of early defeats were not what her fans anticipated from Gauff, who, three years earlier, at 15, proceeded, with astonishing grace and composure, to the fourth round of Wimbledon, defeating her idol Venus Williams along the way. Soon after that win, commentators seemed to be competing to hail Gauffs promise. Chris Evert predicted she would win a Grand Slam championship, even at 18; John McEnroe declared that she would be No. 1. She was now on her fourth year of the tour, and although her skills were steadily improving, she had yet to meet those expectations.

title: The Crypto World Cant Wait for the Merge
description: The cryptocurrency industry has endured a terrible year. A devastating crash wiped nearly $1 trillion from the market, draining the savings of thousands of people. Several companies filed for bankruptcy.

title: With Military Attacks and Mockery, Ukraine Pokes the Russian Bear
description: KYIV, Ukraine  It was pure performance art, pointedly aimed at irking the Kremlin: a mock parade staged by Ukraine featuring dozens of captured Russian tanks in Kyivs central avenue.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, August 26, 2022
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: A Sea Cow That Evoked Mermaids Is Extinct in Chinese Waters, Study Finds
description: The dugong, a species of so-called sea cow that roams the ocean floor in Asia and Africa and is said to have inspired ancient legends of mermaids, has been spotted off Chinas southern coast for centuries.

title: A New Plan for Student Loans
description: President Bidens announcement this week that he would cancel chunks of student loan debt stands to have a major impact for many of the 45 million Americans who owe $1.6 trillion for having gone to college.

title: Conspiracy Theories
description: Senator Ted Cruz has warned that Democrats new spending law will create a shadow army of 87,000 I.R.S. agents. Kari Lake, the Republican candidate for Arizona governor, tied the increase in agents to the F.B.I. search of Donald Trumps Mar-a-Lago home and warned, Not a single one of us is safe. Across social media, conservatives have embraced falsehoods about armed agents, saying that they will target Republicans in particular.

title: When I Come in From the Bullpen, the Other Teams in Trouble
description: That first year, every save chance for Edwin Daz was like a box of flowers delivered to the Mets front door. The Mets would undo the ribbon and lean in for the sweet smell, and the box would blow up in their face.

title: California Bill Could Restrict the Use of Rap Lyrics in Court
description: A California bill that would restrict the use of rap lyrics and other creative works as evidence in criminal proceedings has unanimously passed both the State Senate and Assembly, and could soon be signed into law by Gov. Gavin Newsom.

title: The Finnish National Ballet at 100
description: HELSINKI  What is Finnish about the Finnish National Ballet?

title: How Well Has Jackson Hole Predicted the Economy?
description: Jay Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, gets a half-hour slot (10 a.m. Eastern) this morning to deliver his annual address at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium. On the agenda: an update on the economic outlook, the inflation picture and the path ahead for interest rates.

title: How Californians Are Feeling About the Start of the School Year
description: For a vast majority of Californias roughly six million K-12 students, this month is the beginning of a new school year.

title: The Feds favorite inflation gauge cooled in July.
description: The Federal Reserves preferred measure of inflation eased in July as gas prices fell following a sharp run-up earlier in the summer, a widely expected moderation that is nevertheless likely to be welcome news for policymakers as they battle the most rapid price gains in decades.

title: Has the Fight Against Antisemitism Lost Its Way?
description: Over the past 18 months, Americas most prominent Jewish organizations have done something extraordinary. They have accused the worlds leading human rights organizations of promoting hatred of Jews.

title: Moderna Sues Pfizer and BioNTech Over Covid Vaccine Technology
description: The vaccine manufacturer Moderna sued Pfizer and BioNTech on Friday, claiming that its rivals Covid-19 shot copied groundbreaking technology that Moderna had developed years before the pandemic.

title: U.S. income growth slowed in July, and consumer spending barely grew.
description: Americans incomes rose more slowly last month  but, for once, those gains werent swallowed up by higher prices.

title: What to Do if Market Drops Took a Bite Out of Your College Savings
description: Many families saving for college are seeing red  on their 529 plan statements.

title: Some Monkeys Use Stone Tools for Pleasure, Study Suggests
description: Many monkeys are skilled stone handlers, using rocks to dig up roots, cut plants and crack open an array of delicacies, including fruits and nuts.

title: U.S. and China Announce Deal to Share Audits of U.S.-Listed Chinese Firms
description: American and Chinese officials said Friday that they had reached an agreement to allow accounting firms in China to share more information with American regulators about the finances of Chinese companies listed on U.S. stock exchanges.

title: Stocks Plunge After Fed Chair Warns of Pain From Inflation Fight
description: Wall Street recoiled on Friday, after the head of the Federal Reserve delivered a stern warning that the central banks campaign to lower inflation by raising interest rates is unconditional even if it leads to pain for households, businesses and in turn stock prices.

title: Documents at Mar-a-Lago Could Compromise Human Intelligence Sources, Affidavit Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments search of former President Donald J. Trumps Florida home was spurred by the discovery that he had retained a trove of highly classified material that included documents related to the use of clandestine human sources in intelligence gathering, according to a redacted version of the affidavit used to obtain the search warrant.

title: What Is in a Search Warrant Affidavit?
description: The expected release of the affidavit that accompanied the Justice Departments application for a warrant to search former President Donald J. Trumps residence in Florida is exceedingly rare.

title: What the Champions League Is Lacking
description: PARIS  There will be stories, of course. There are always stories. The Champions League delivers them so frequently and so reliably that it is impossible to dismiss the nagging suspicion that all of this might just be scripted, the product of some complex simulation being run from a secret lair in Nyon.

title: How to Get Heart Patients to Take Their Pills? Give Them Just One.
description: Heart disease kills more people than any other condition, but despite advances in treatment and prevention, patients often do not stick to their medication regimens. Now researchers may have found a solution: a so-called polypill that combines three drugs needed to prevent cardiovascular trouble.

title: Are You Strapped In for The Patient? The Therapist Is.
description: Most actors are attached to their jobs. Steve Carell was padlocked to his.

title: Watch live: Jerome Powell speaks at the Feds Jackson Hole conference.
description: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, is speaking at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium, the central banks most prominent annual gathering.

title: Fed Chair Signals More Rate Increases Ahead, Shaking Wall Street
description: JACKSON, Wyo.  Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, delivered a sobering message on Friday, saying the Fed must continue to raise interest rates  and keep them elevated for a while  to bring the fastest inflation in decades back under control.

title: Zelensky is under pressure over when and how to launch a long-anticipated counteroffensive.
description: As the bloody artillery battle in Ukraines east settles into a stalemate, the war appears now to be a waiting game for a long-promised Ukrainian counteroffensive.

title: How to Do Everything
description: A guide to life, drawn from seven years of the magazines Tip column.

title: To Make Money in the Stock Market, Do Nothing
description: The stock market fell so sharply at the beginning of the year that it felt at times as if it would never come back.

title: Jared Kushners Soulless Memoir and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

title: A smarter transition to electric vehicles
description: We got some big news from California this week: Officials there set into motion a plan thatll ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035. The decision is expected to accelerate the global transition to electric vehicles.

title: How British energy prices are set.
description: Some 24 million British households received distressing news on Friday: Starting Oct. 1, they will be paying 80 percent more for energy, or a total of 3,549 pounds over the course of a year for a typical British home.

title: Britney Spears and Elton Johns Mash-up, and 8 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: This is Priya, once again taking over for Sam!

title: Keeping His Weed Happy
Trump Lawyers Face a Deadline in Their Request for a Special Master
description: Former President Donald J. Trump and his lawyers were due on Friday to file court papers clarifying a request this week seeking an independent arbiter to review the hundreds of pages of sensitive documents that were seized during the search of his Florida residence.

title: At M.T.A.s First Congestion Pricing Hearing, Critics Abound
description: Across almost seven hours Thursday night, the speeches grew in volume and intensity  a cacophony of New Yorkers brought together over Zoom to either praise or denounce one of the citys most contentious transportation projects.

title: Steven Hoffenberg, Debt Baron Who Ran a Vast Fraud, Dies at 77
description: Steven J. Hoffenberg, a brash New York debt mogul who spent 18 years in federal prison after admitting to running a fraud scheme that prosecutors said was then among the largest such crimes in U.S. history, was found dead on Tuesday in the modest apartment in Derby, Conn., where he had lived for about two years. He was 77.

title: Title Search: How Well Do You Know Speculative Fiction?
description: Can you find the titles of these 21 books that take the reader to other worlds?

title: E.P.A. to Designate PFAS, or Forever Chemicals, as Hazardous
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency said on Friday it will designate the two most commonly detected toxic forever chemicals, which have been linked to cancer and have been found in everything from drinking water to furniture, as hazardous substances.

title: The Secrets Lurking Inside Matisses Red Studio
description: A flowered dress. A naked teenager. A Russian millionaire. A fancy room that hides secrets.

title: The Weekender
description: A mystery in the desert for 50 years. Also in this edition: Greek party islands that want to change their image, and how to get a book published.

title: At Chaotic Seasons Close, PGA Tour Banks on Patience and Its Stars
description: ATLANTA  The conversation happened two days after Cameron Smith charged into Rory McIlroys lengthening catalog of letdowns.

title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: Early in this documentary from Ukraine, a family in the war-torn region of Donbass sets up a makeshift studio in their living room to shoot some scenes for a film. Against a wall draped with black cloth, each family member  the single mother, Anna, her two teenage daughters and two little boys  takes turns speaking to the camera. When one of the boys slams the clapperboard to start a new scene, we hear, instead of the clap, the sound of a bomb: The screen cuts to Anna and her sons crouched in their basement as a neighbors house is shelled by Russian forces. Is this reality? Or another scene from the movie-within-the-movie?

title: James Hannaham Resists the Very Idea of Literary Genres
description: Ive been savoring Blair Fells The Sign for Home for a long time, because Covid killed my attention span and lately I can only read novels on planes. Blair is an old friend, but I was a fan of his work before I met him. He used to write a soap opera called Burning Habits that appeared in East Village gay bars in the 90s. This book has a lot of the things Ive always loved about his writing. Its a hilarious, peculiar and very touching story about a deaf, blind Jehovahs Witness boy and his gay interpreter (Blair has been a terp for 30 years!) who try to find the boys long-lost love together. It gets very dramatic! Next up are Airea D. Matthewss Simulacra, Peter Rocks Passersthrough, a couple of Rough Guide travel books and The Anarchist Review of Books.

title: Affirmative Action Was Banned at Two Top Universities. They Say They Need It.
description: It has been more than 15 years since two of the countrys top public university systems, the University of Michigan and the University of California, were forced to stop using affirmative action in admissions.

title: Fighting Between U.S. and Iran-Backed Militias Escalates in Syria
description: Militias backed by Irans Revolutionary Guards force attacked a U.S. military base in southern Syria with drones recently and on the same day, a different base used by the U.S.-led coalition near Syrias eastern border with Iraq came under rocket fire.

title: The Toll of Student Debt in the U.S.
description: The amount of student loan debt held in America has grown to roughly the size of the economy of Brazil or Australia as the cost of higher education has skyrocketed over the last half-century.

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center Chooses Dance Veteran as Leader
description: The pandemic brought a series of changes to the Baryshnikov Arts Center in Manhattan, forcing it to cancel two years of live performances and find new ways to connect with the public, including starting a streaming platform.

title: Wonking Out: Europe and the Economics of Blackmail
description: Four decades ago I spent a year working in the U.S. government, on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers. (For those wondering: Yes, this was the Reagan administration; no, I wasnt a Republican.) It was a technocratic job. I was the chief international economist; the chief domestic economist was a guy named Larry Summers. What ever happened to him?

title: What to Know About White Mulberry Leaf
description: Last December, Loretta McClintock, the wife of Representative Tom McClintock from California, died unexpectedly in her home in California. The cause of death was not released at the time. This week, an investigation by Kaiser Health News revealed that the coroner who performed her autopsy linked her death to white mulberry leaf, a centuries-old herbal remedy which, in recent years, has been marketed as a supplement for weight loss and diabetes management.

title: Latvia tears down a controversial Soviet-era monument in its capital.
description: The nearly 260-foot-tall obelisk, erected during the Soviet rule of Latvia, had towered in a park in the Baltic nations capital for nearly four decades.

title: Is Bidens Student Loan Forgiveness Plan the Right Approach?
description: To the Editor:

title: Injuries Dim Optimism Around Jets and Giants as N.F.L. Season Nears
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Zach Wilson, the centerpiece of the Jets rebuild, stood in a shaded area near a small weight-lifting area at the teams joint practice against the Giants on Thursday.

title: Ethiopian Airstrike Hits Kindergarten as Fighting Spreads in Tigray
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  An Ethiopian government airstrike ripped through a kindergarten in the northern Tigray region on Friday, killing at least seven people including several children, medics said, as the hunger-stricken region plunged into a new round of fighting.

title: A Spicy Tomato Pasta for All Seasons
description: Hi, lovely people. Its Margaux filling in for Em. Ive missed you!

title: Ringworm? Tatiss Explanations Stretch Common Sense, Experts Say.
description: In the days since he was suspended for 80 games because a prohibited steroid was found in his system, the San Diego Padres star Fernando Tatis Jr. has insisted he wasnt doping but has given shifting explanations about what condition he was trying to treat.

title: Here Are the Challenges Ahead for Californias Ban on Gas Cars
description: California has laid out an audacious goal: In 13 years, it should no longer be possible to buy a new car that runs purely on gasoline anywhere in the state.

title: Decades Later, a Composer Revisits the Piano Concerto
description: It took the composer William Bolcom over 40 years to follow his first piano concerto with a second one.

title: Mar-a-Lagos time in the spotlight began long before Trump.
description: Mar-a-Lago, Donald J. Trumps opulent 20-acre private club and residence in Palm Beach, Fla., was nearly a rival for the White House during his presidency. It was a backdrop for meetings with Republican allies and foreign leaders while being a potent symbol of his personal brand.

title: The Invitation Review: Bringing Down the Haunted House
description: The Invitation, a brittle, droning excursion into gothic horror, primarily takes place at a manor in the English countryside. The setting is admissible, if unimaginative: the exterior of the estate appears constructed of Playmobil; coated in cobwebs, its dingy indoors most closely resemble a dungeon.

title: 3 Party Pies You Can Eat With Your Hands
description: A golden-domed, syrupy-centered fruit pie may be the ideal dessert to serve at a summer gathering. But for eating out of hand, say, at a Labor Day cookout or picnic, a pie bar is superior.

title: Love Letter: Missing Your Sons Ex-Girlfriend?
description: Most of the submissions we receive at Modern Love are about romantic relationships. That is far from a surprise, but it is a shame.

title: New York City Finally Gets Its Aman
description: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, well recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: The Way to Slow Climate Change Is as Close as Your City Hall or School Board
description: Three months after taking office as Americas 46th president, Joe Biden made a solemn pledge to the world: He declared that the United States, which is more responsible for the climate crisis than any other nation, would cut its greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030 from their 2005 peak.

title: Only Connect: Finding a Way Into Kinetic Lights Wired
description: Am I missing something here? is a question prompted by many dance performances. In my mind, the thought often has an anxious tone, since I consider it my job as a critic to try to miss as little as possible. When I attended the New York premiere of Kinetic Lights Wired at the Shed on Thursday, the question was especially loud in my head. But even more unusual was the unequivocal clarity of the answer. I was missing something. By design.

title: Joe E. Tata, Peach Pit Owner in Beverly Hills, 90210, Dies at 85
description: Joe E. Tata, a character actor whose roles in a long television career included henchmen on the original Batman series and bit parts on The Rockford Files, but who was best known as the good-natured owner of the Peach Pit diner on the hit 1990s teenage drama Beverly Hills, 90210, died on Thursday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 85.

title: On Remote Farms and in City Gardens, a Native American Movement Grows
description: SOUTH ONONDAGA, N.Y.  The solstice sun lingered overhead as Angela Ferguson surveyed the green hills of the Onondaga Nation in central New York.

title: The Fed Chairs Challenge: Be Clear, but Not Too Certain
description: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, has declared war on inflation, and on Friday he was specific about his battlefield tactics. Julys increase in the target range was the second 75-basis-point increase in as many meetings, and I said then that another unusually large increase could be appropriate at our next meeting, Powell said at an economic symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyo. (Heres the full text of his remarks.)

title: Michigan G.O.P. Lining Up Behind Conspiracy Theorist for Attorney General
description: Several weeks after the 2020 election, as Donald J. Trump worked to overturn his defeat, he called a Republican lawmaker in Michigan with an urgent request. Mr. Trump had seen a report that made wild claims about rigged voting machines in a rural northern county in the state. He wanted his allies to look into it.

title: Affidavit Puts Focus on the Question of Obstruction
description: The question of obstruction was front and center when the affidavit for the federal search warrant to look at former President Donald J. Trumps property was in part made public on Friday.

title: White House Snaps Back at Twitter Critics of Student Loan Relief
description: The official White House Twitter account, @WhiteHouse, normally traffics in staid infographics and excerpts from temperate government speeches, but on Thursday night it took an aggressive turn.

title: This Back-to-School Lunch Gets Better With Time
description: I love cooking. Thats why I hated packing school lunches for my three children. If the joy of feeding them is giving them something delicious, then it was joyless to send them off with meals that languished for hours in warm classrooms and were decent at best.

title: NBC Discusses Ending Prime-Time Lineup at 10 p.m.
description: NBC executives have had discussions about ending the networks prime-time lineup at 10 p.m. and turning the hour over to local stations, according to two people with knowledge of the talks.

title: Sy Johnson, Arranger Who Worked Closely With Mingus, Dies at 92
description: Sy Johnson, a Renaissance jazz master  pianist, composer, journalist, photographer  who made his biggest impact as a frequent arranger, orchestrator and all-around right-hand man for the celebrated bassist Charles Mingus, died on July 26 in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: John Lithgow on an Actors Education
description: For the next few months, were sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcasts archives. This weeks segments first appeared in 2011 and 2021, respectively.

title: Riders Catch a Little Too Much Air on a Detroit Slide
description: A ride down the Giant Slide at Belle Isle Park has been a mainstay of Detroit summers since 1967. Generations of residents have climbed the steps, scooched their legs into burlap bags and experienced the thrill of swooping down the 50-foot slide.

title: The Affidavit for the Search of Trumps Home, Annotated
description: Read the affidavit that outlined the Justice Departments case for obtaining a warrant to search Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trumps Florida home and private club, on Aug. 8.

title: Dont Skip Therapy Because of Work
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: This Is Not the Monkeypox That Doctors Thought They Knew
description: Early in the monkeypox outbreak, a man in his 20s arrived at an emergency department in Northern California, tiny blisters on his lips, hands and back. Within 12 hours, doctors diagnosed him with monkeypox.

title: Ukraine Weighs a Risky Offensive to Break Out of a Stalemate
description: KYIV, Ukraine  For months Russian and Ukrainian soldiers have waged a brutal war across a 1,500-mile front line, inflicting casualties, fighting to the point of exhaustion and making slow gains in territory when they were not suffering costly setbacks.

title: Are You Even Fun? A Mostly Unscientific Quiz.
description: Fun. What is it? How do we have it? Will we ever have it again?

title: Edward Enninful Also Wears Prada
description: LONDON  Edward Enninful, the editor of British Vogue, gave me a list of friends to contact for this article.

title: A Child Has Monkeypox in New York City, but the Epidemic May Be Waning
description: Health officials said on Thursday that a child had been infected with monkeypox in New York City, the citys first known pediatric case.

title: The Liberal Justice Who Warned Against an Activist Supreme Court
description: In his concurring opinion in the Dobbs abortion case, which overturned Roe v. Wade, Chief Justice John Roberts invoked the wisdom of a thoughtful member of this court  namely, Felix Frankfurter. Like Frankfurter, who served as a justice from 1939 to 1962, Roberts argued that the Supreme Court should preserve its legitimacy by respecting precedents, deciding cases narrowly rather than broadly, and in most cases deferring to the democratic political process rather than second-guessing Congress and state legislatures.

title: We Knew the Justice Department Case Was Righteous. This Affidavit Confirms It.
description: We always knew that whatever the information about the Mar-a-Lago search that would be released by a federal court, it would not help Donald Trump.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Poking the Bear
description: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, well choose three nonfiction films  classics, overlooked recent docs and more  that will reward your time.

title: Catching Up With Star Trek, the Quiet Franchise
description: Star Trek got a head start in the television-universe game. Four series, beginning with Star Trek: The Next Generation, came out in succession and ran almost continuously from 1988 to 2005, well before the current iterations of the Marvel and Star Wars TV empires were in place.

title: Seattle Gives Rookie a Contract That Matches His Ambition
description: In spring training, Julio Rodrguez, a Seattle Mariners prospect, said he had no doubt that he could be an All-Star who clubs 500 home runs and ends Seattles 20-season playoff drought. He even thought he could eventually lead the team to its first World Series title.

title: Virginia Patton Moss, Its a Wonderful Life Actress, Dies at 97
description: Virginia Patton Moss, the last surviving adult member of the cast of Frank Capras Its a Wonderful Life, who, three years after that film was released, left Hollywood to find her own wonderful life raising a family in Ann Arbor, Mich., died on Aug. 18 in Albany, Ga. She was 97.

title: What to Know About the Allegations Against Matt Araiza
description: The Buffalo Bills cut the rookie punter Matt Araiza on Saturday, two days after he was accused in a lawsuit of raping a 17-year-old girl last October. The lawsuit also accused two of his teammates at San Diego State of rape stemming from an incident at an off-campus party.

title: Mar-a-Lago Search Followed Many Attempts to Secure Trump Documents
description: When the F.B.I. descended on Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trumps home and club in Florida, on Aug. 8 and carted off several boxes of sensitive documents, it was only after government officials had spent more than a year using various  and far less invasive  means of trying to secure the materials or get them back.

title: Joey DeFrancesco, Reigning King of the Jazz Organ, Dies at 51
description: Joey DeFrancesco, who was widely credited with bringing the organ back into vogue in jazz circles in recent decades, died on Thursday. He was 51.

title: DeSantis Suspends 4 Elected School Board Members After Report on Parkland
description: MIAMI  Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida suspended four elected members of the Broward County school board on Friday, following the recommendation of a grand jury impaneled to look into school safety and other issues after the mass school shooting in Parkland that left 17 people dead in 2018.

title: Classified Material on Human Intelligence Sources Helped Trigger Alarm
description: WASHINGTON  They risk imprisonment or death stealing the secrets of their own governments. Their identities are among the most closely protected information inside American intelligence and law enforcement agencies. Losing even one of them can set back American foreign intelligence operations for years.

title: How Will the Student Loan Forgiveness Plan Affect You?
description: What would you do if $10,000, or even as much as $20,000, in federal student loan debt was wiped away completely? What is suddenly possible that might not have been before?

title: Not the Win We Wanted, but a Win Nonetheless
description: The Biden administration has finally delivered on its long anticipated student loan cancellation plans. The timing is critical: Midterm elections are around the corner. Just a few weeks ago, the consensus was that the Democratic Party was in trouble. But a series of policy wins has changed that narrative.

title: In Praise of Sweat
A Journey Into the Misinformation Fever Swamps
description: Fake news has gone from a hot buzzword popularized during the 2016 presidential campaign to an ever-present phenomenon known more formally as misinformation or disinformation.

title: Republicans, Once Outraged by Mar-a-Lago Search, Become Quieter as Details Emerge
description: In the minutes and hours after the F.B.I.s search of former President Donald J. Trumps residence in Florida this month, his supporters did not hesitate to denounce what they saw as a blatant abuse of power and outrageous politicization of the Justice Department.

title: Biden Gave In to Pressure on Student Debt Relief After Months of Doubt
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden and Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader, boarded Air Force One on May 17 in Buffalo after visiting with the families of 10 people gunned down in a supermarket. The emotions from the mass shooting were raw, but Mr. Schumer had something else on his mind, too.

title: Takeaways From the Affidavit Used to Justify the Search of Mar-a-Lago
description: The release on Friday of a partly redacted affidavit used by the Justice Department to justify its search of former President Donald J. Trumps Florida residence included information that provides greater insight into the ongoing investigation into how he handled sensitive national security documents he took with him from the White House.

title: Doug Mastriano Wore a Confederate Uniform in a Faculty Photo
description: Doug Mastriano, the far-right Republican nominee for governor of Pennsylvania, wore a Confederate uniform for a faculty photo at the Army War College that surfaced on Friday.

title: Inside the 20-Month Drive to Get Trump to Return Presidential Material
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government tried and failed repeatedly for more than a year and a half to retrieve classified and sensitive documents from former President Donald J. Trump before resorting to a search of his Mar-a-Lago property this month, according to government documents and statements by Mr. Trumps lawyers.

title: Brandon Holt, Tracy Austins Son, Wins a Spot in U.S. Open Main Draw
description: Tracy Austin put her hands to her head, then buried her face in them and, finally, raised two fists to the sky with a triumphant smile. It was not quite as exuberant as her celebration when she won the U.S. Open for the first time in 1979. But it was pretty close.

title: Possibility of Obstruction Looms Over Trump After Thwarted Efforts to Recover Documents
description: WASHINGTON  When the Justice Department proposed redactions to the affidavit underlying the warrant used to search former President Donald J. Trumps residence, prosecutors made clear that they feared the former president and his allies might take any opportunity to intimidate witnesses or otherwise illegally obstruct their investigation.

title: Confirmation, e.g.
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  What a tricky quintet of loosely conjoined little themeless grids we get today! I flew through the northeast corner, sprinkled in a couple of entries at the bottom and on the west side, and then just  stopped. I couldnt rustle up a thing in the center and top of this puzzle for a long time, until I recalibrated my solving sensibilities to Andrew Linzers excellent, humorous wordplay.

title: Quotation of the Day: In Florida, Cautiously Navigating How to Teach
description: Gatsby is about the futility of the American dream. If I talk about the futility of the American dream, is that going to be indoctrinating them?

title: Corrections: Aug. 27, 2022
description: An article on Thursday about Californias plan to ban the sale of gasoline-powered cars featured a quotation that misstated the distinction of the California measure. While California is the first U.S. state government to mandate zero-emission vehicles, it is not the only government to have done so. (British Columbia has similar rules in place.)

title: Chris Evert Needs Everyone to Listen
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  All the medical advancements that helped save Chris Everts life could not save her sister. Jeanne Evert Dubin died of ovarian cancer in February 2020, at age 62, her illness discovered only after it had reached its deadliest stages.

title: War Brings Ukraines Women New Roles and New Dangers
description: CHERNIHIV, Ukraine  The road to the training site was lined with crumbling homes and damaged buildings, a reminder of how war had consumed the northern Ukrainian city of Chernihiv just months ago.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SATURDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Back to School in DeSantiss Florida, as Teachers Look Over Their Shoulders
description: Erin Brown, a teacher in St. Johns County, Fla., typically keeps a gay pride flag hanging up in her classroom. As the faculty sponsor of a Gay-Straight Alliance club at her high school, she wants her students to know they are safe with her.

title: Election Data Breach Attracts Georgia Investigators
description: The day after Donald J. Trumps supporters stormed the Capitol, a small group working on his behalf traveled to rural Coffee County, Ga., about 200 miles southeast of Atlanta.

title: How 3 NASA Missions Could Send Astronauts Back to the Moon
description: By the end of this decade, humans could walk on the moon once again. Heres how NASA plans to send them there.

title: Serena Williams at the U.S. Open: How to Watch Her Next Match
Ready for a Night Out? Hire a Disco Nanny.
description: Three months before Olga Lopatina and Emiliano Beltrami make their annual August pilgrimage to Mykonos, they start making reservations.

title: How Do I Time a Move From One Rental Apartment to Another?
description: Q: I am moving from Connecticut to Manhattan later this year, and Im concerned about how to time the move. My current landlord requires 60 days notice to move out. But from what I have seen, most apartments in New York are not listed until 30 days before they become available, and are rented even faster than that. Im also considering renting in a co-op or condo, and those approval processes seem long. How do I time this right so I dont end up paying for two apartments at once, or worse, giving up my apartment without a place to live?

title: How a Public Tennis Court Attendant Spends His Sundays
description: At exactly 8 oclock the call went out. Tennis time!

title: The Sixth Love Language Does Not Exist
The Robber Baron Who Remade Wall Street in His Own Image
description: On April 5, 1882, Theodore Roosevelt stood in the New York State Assembly and demanded an investigation. The indignant 23-year-old accused a clique of swindlers, wealthy stock gamblers, men whose financial dishonesty is a matter of common notoriety, of corruptly monopolizing New York Citys elevated railroads. The plots mastermind, he implied, was Jay Gould.

title: New York City Sets a High Bar for Lifeguards. That Could Be a Problem.
description: As temperatures climbed into the high 80s on a sunny afternoon this week, dozens of people trying to cool off at the public pool in McCarren Park in Williamsburg had only half the usual space, as the other side sat empty, blocked by traffic cones and caution tape.

title: Octopuses Dont Have Backbones  or Rights
description: Lab rats have rights. Before researchers in the United States can experiment on the animals, they need approval from committees that ensure they follow federal regulations for housing and handling the creatures humanely. The same is true of scientists working with mice, monkeys, fish or finches.

title: Does Watching College Football on TV Have to Be So Miserable?
description: It is, lets say, 8:43 p.m. on a Saturday. You are watching a college football game that is taking place at this hour despite being played in the Midwest in November, and the people in the stadium, which is not entirely full, look very cold and a little put off. The season schedule said kickoff was at 8 p.m., but it didnt actually take place until 8:18. In the 25 minutes that have elapsed, play has been interrupted for three commercial breaks. Each advertisement shown during these breaks has been for pickup trucks.

title: The Best Tool We Have for Self-Harming and Suicidal Teens
description: Parents seeking therapy for teenagers who self-harm or suffer from anxiety, depression or suicidal thoughts face an imposing thicket of treatment options and acronyms: cognitive behavioral therapy (C.B.T.), parent management training (P.M.T.), collaborative assessment and management of suicidality (CAMS), acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) and others.

title: Planning for Your Retirement, and for a Childs Special Needs, All at Once
description: Rachel Nagler, 39, has worked part time since she was 22, but she will never be financially independent, according to her father. She is legally blind with a seizure disorder and mild cognitive impairment, the result of birth trauma.

title: Come for the Golden Gate Bridge and Cable Cars. Stay for the Summer Shivers.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  While Americans from Seattle to Memphis to New York sweated their way through the swampy summer of 2022, here was the scene on an August afternoon at Fishermans Wharf, on the northern tip of San Francisco: Among a group of friends from Germany gawking at dozens of barking sea lions splayed on floating docks, one was bundled in a down jacket and another in a sweatshirt, and a third was shivering despite a red checkered scarf worn like a shawl.

title: This Teen Was Prescribed 10 Psychiatric Drugs. Shes Not Alone.
description: One morning in the fall of 2017, Renae Smith, a high school freshman on Long Island, N.Y., could not get out of bed, overwhelmed at the prospect of going to school. In the following days, her anxiety mounted into despair.

title: In Finland, a Partying Prime Minister Draws Tuts, and Cheers
description: HELSINKI, Finland  Last fall, Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland, a 36-year-old leather-jacket-wearing regular at rock festivals, vowed that she wanted to live like a person my age and shake up the highest office in the government.

title: At One of Canadas Top Destinations, Tourists Are Back but Much Has Changed
description: A little over a year had passed since my last visits to the Alberta mountain towns of Banff and Canmore, and the contrast was startling. After a protracted pandemic-induced absence, tourists were back.

title: The 5 Love Languages at 30
description: The pastor Gary Chapman created the concept of love languages 30 years ago. In his hugely popular book, The 5 Love Languages, he proposed that the ways people prefer to have love communicated to them fall into five categories, or languages: acts of service, words of affirmation, quality time, receiving gifts and physical touch.

title: Beefcake, Goethes Boswell and the Greeks
description: Dear readers,

title: Womens Work Is Never Done
description: WASHINGTON  Its nice to see that the Democrats are back on track.

title: A Holy British Island, Where the Reckless Try to Outrace the Tide
description: HOLY ISLAND, England  The off-duty police officer was confident he could make it back to the mainland without incident, despite islanders warning him not to risk the incoming tide.

title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes.

title: Paddling Makes a Comeback in a Missouri School District
description: A Missouri school districts announcement that it is bringing back paddling drew a lot of attention and dismay this week. But corporal punishment  with an interruption, perhaps, for the coronavirus pandemic in some places  never went away in a large number of schools.

title: Promoting His Memoir, Kushner Offers Tortured Defenses of Trump
description: WASHINGTON  Making the rounds promoting his new memoir, Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of former President Donald J. Trump, this week ran into the question he has managed for months to avoid commenting on publicly: Did he agree with Mr. Trumps false claim that the 2020 election was stolen?

title: Bidens Big Dreams Meet the Limits of Imperfect Tools
description: WASHINGTON  President Bidens move this week to cancel student loan debt for tens of millions of borrowers and reduce future loan payments for millions more comes with a huge catch, economists warn: It does almost nothing to limit the skyrocketing cost of college and could very well fuel even faster tuition increases in the future.

title: The Long Road Ahead for Colonial Reparations
description: What do former colonial powers owe the descendants of those they colonized?

title: You Want an Electric Car With a 300-Mile Range? When Was the Last Time You Drove 300 Miles?
description: Throughout the history of Americas love affair with the car, nothing has succeeded quite like excess. Electric vehicles are heading down that same path. Give an E.V. a big enough battery and a fast-charging network, and suddenly you have the kind of vehicle weve always loved in this country: big, heavy, powerful and ready to head off into the sunset at a moments notice.

title: Harry Styles Walks a Fine Line
description: Harry Styles, this summers pop prince, has earned his crown by capturing the fantasies of millions and taking what seems like a groundbreaking approach to the presentation of gender fluidity and sexual identity. While expanding his kingdom and conquering pop culture, Mr. Styles has  with his last two album releases  also been accused of queerbaiting: In this case, using queerness to burnish his celebrity without explicitly claiming to be queer.

title: Lower Black and Latino Pass Rates Dont Make a Test Racist
description: The Association of Social Work Boards administers tests typically required for the licensure of social workers. Apparently, this amounts to a kind of racism that must be reckoned with.

title: Republicans Would Like to Offer You Some Resentment
description: The Republican response to President Bidens student loan forgiveness program is to try to turn the issue into a culture war.

title: As DeSantis Campaigns on Education, Crist Picks Teacher as Running Mate
description: MIAMI  In choosing the head of the largest teachers union in the Southeast as his running mate, Charlie Crist, the Democratic nominee for Florida governor, said he found a partner to embody the caring and empathy that he argues Gov. Ron DeSantis sorely lacks.

title: The New Big Brother: Your Company Is Watching You
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbias Leader Cancels EuroPride. Organizers Say They Will Go Ahead Anyway.
description: President Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia announced on Saturday that he would not permit EuroPride, an annual weeklong gay pride event, to take place next month in his countrys capital, Belgrade, shocking the events organizers, who denounced the decision and vowed to go ahead regardless.

title: Western officials criticize Russia for blocking a joint U.N. document on nuclear disarmament.
description: Russia blocked the adoption of a joint statement to close out a United Nations conference on an ongoing nuclear arms treaty, Western officials said, a diplomatic broadside that underscored the global ramifications of the war in Ukraine.

title: How to Avoid a Nuclear Disaster in Ukraine
description: There were reports on Saturday that the International Atomic Energy Agency has a team of experts ready to visit Ukraines Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant within days. It would not be a minute too soon: Artillery shells are landing with chilling regularity in and around the facility, Europes largest nuclear power station.

title: Ashes of Nichelle Nichols Are Set for Journey to Deep Space
description: The ashes of Nichelle Nichols, who played Lieutenant Uhura in the original Star Trek television series and died in July, will be launched into space later this year.

title: Judge Recommends Rejecting Bid by Sept. 11 Families to Seize Frozen Afghan Funds
description: WASHINGTON  A federal magistrate judge has recommended rejecting the effort by relatives of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to seize $3.5 billion in frozen Afghan central bank funds to pay off judgment debts owed by the Taliban  in part because doing so, she said, would effectively recognize the Taliban as the legitimate government of Afghanistan.

title: Intelligence Officials Will Assess Security Risks From Mar-a-Lago Documents
description: WASHINGTON  U.S. intelligence officials will conduct a review to assess the possible risks to national security from former President Donald J. Trumps handling of classified documents after the F.B.I. retrieved boxes containing sensitive material from Mar-a-Lago, according to a letter to lawmakers.

title: With Disaster Looming, Inspectors Set to Visit Ukraine Nuclear Plant
description: KYIV, Ukraine  As renewed shelling intensified fears about a nuclear accident at the Zaporizhzhia power plant, the Ukrainian authorities stepped up emergency drills on Saturday and rushed to hand out potassium iodide, a drug that can protect people from radiation-induced thyroid cancer, to tens of thousands of people living near the facility.

title: Lessons Learned, Israels Unlikely Islamist Kingmaker Looks Ahead
description: KAFR QASSEM, Israel  As Israel heads this fall into yet another election campaign, with the likelihood of yet another stalemate looming, one potential kingmaker is sitting on the sidelines eager to take part in the countrys next government.

title: Abbott to Restart Production of Similac Baby Formula
description: Abbott Nutrition, which shut down a plant in Michigan in February amid contamination concerns, triggering a national shortage of baby formula, said on Friday that it was set to resume making its leading formula, Similac.

title: Animal Hybrids
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Ori Brian is a product manager at Amazon who currently lives in Los Angeles but is relocating soon to London. He became interested in crossword puzzles while at the University of Chicago, solving with friends in the dining hall, and quickly moved on to constructing. This is his ninth puzzle for The Times since his debut in 2016, and his first Sunday grid.

title: Judge Signals Intent to Appoint Special Master in Mar-a-Lago Search
description: A federal judge in Florida gave notice on Saturday of her preliminary intent to appoint an independent arbiter, known as a special master, to conduct a review of the highly sensitive documents that were seized by the F.B.I. this month during a search of Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trumps club and residence in Palm Beach.

title: Buffalo Bills Cut Matt Araiza Amid Rape Lawsuit
description: The Buffalo Bills cut Matt Araiza on Saturday, two days after the rookie punter was accused in a lawsuit of raping a 17-year-old girl last October with two of his teammates at San Diego State.

title: Racial Slur During College Volleyball Game Leads to Fan Suspension
description: A Duke University womens volleyball player who is Black was called a racial slur during a game Friday night in Utah, prompting Brigham Young University to ban a fan from sporting events and Duke University to change the venue of a tournament game on Saturday.

title: Mets of Yesteryear Suddenly Feel Theyre Part of Something
description: When Jay Hook threw out a ceremonial first pitch to Mike Piazza on Saturday night, it showed off the Mets newfound ability to celebrate the entirety of the franchises 60-year history in one big event.

title: Corrections: Aug. 28, 2022
description: An article on Page 36 this weekend about the artist Cecilia Vicua misstates the date of her painting Leoparda de Ojitos. It is 1977, not 1976.

title: Pakistan Hit by Deadly Floods of Epic Proportions
description: Devastating floods have surged across Pakistan, overflowing riverbanks and bridges, inundating houses and fields and killing more than 100 people this weekend, officials said late Saturday.

title: Why NASA Is Going Back to the Moon
description: We are going.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SUNDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Serena Williams Always Made a Strong First Impression
description: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

title: As Covid Guidance Evolves, So Does a Virus Briefing
description: This month, the Coronavirus Briefing newsletter  an account of pandemic news that began in January 2020  transitioned to the Virus Briefing. The new weekly newsletter, written by Jonathan Wolfe, a Times reporter, expands the briefings mission to include updates and expert insight on the varying diseases and pathogens  such as monkeypox and poliovirus  that are spreading across the globe.

title: A Tiny House in Manhattan Has a Link to the Underground Railroad
description: In a city of showy skyscrapers climbing ever higher in their bids to catch the eye, the beguiling little brick-and-wood house at 2 White Street in TriBeCa is striking precisely because of its humble scale and design.

title: Fall Vaccination Campaign Will Bring New Shots, Worse Access
description: Long past the point when pollsters said there were no more Americans willing to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, Coral Garner kept finding them.

title: I Often Wish the Morning Hour Would Last Longer
description: Dear Diary:

title: Power and Grit That Changed the Game
description: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

title: Its How You Wear It
description: MoMA PS1s beloved Warm Up party took a hiatus this season and was replaced by Summer Fridays, featuring D.J. sets in the courtyard from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m. The Aug. 19 lineup featured Jenifa Mayanja and attracted a young, artsy crowd who looked effortlessly cool.

title: U.S. Warships Sail Taiwan Strait, Defying Chinese Pressure
description: HONG KONG  The U.S. Navy said that two of its warships sailed through the Taiwan Strait on Sunday, the first such passage by American ships since China began large-scale military exercises in response to a visit to Taiwan by Speaker Nancy Pelosi early this month.

title: Quotation of the Day: Better Boosters, Even as Access Is Scaled Back
description: A year ago, there was all this money for advertising, and they were throwing money at vaccines. Now, its like nobody cares.

title: The Toss
description: A detailed look at a critical element of elite serving that can determine who wins each point in a tennis match.

title: Counting the Population Has Always Been Political
description: The U.S. census has inspired a surprising amount of poetry, Dan Bouk notes in his endearingly nerdy new book, Democracys Data. And I doubt this is because census rhymes with so many relevant words: fences, defenses, Mike Pences.

title: After 20 Years in a Mens Prison, a Trans Woman Returns Home
description: Everybody Black knows how to react to a tragedy, James Hannaham wrote in his 2015 novel Delicious Foods. Just bring out a wheelbarrow full of the Same Old Anger, dump it all over the Usual Frustration and water it with Somebody Oughtas.  Mention the Holy Spirit whenever possible. In his new novel, Didnt Nobody Give a Shit What Happened to Carlotta, the plot converges on a wake, and its cast of characters gleefully adhere to that pronouncement. We may understand its mechanisms, but Hannahams bumper-car narrative still astonishes.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: In New Hampshire, Republicans Weigh Another Hard-Right Candidate
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  He has said the states popular Republican governor is a Chinese Communist sympathizer, called for the repeal of the 17th Amendment allowing direct popular election of senators and raised the possibility of abolishing the F.B.I.

title: The Offices Last Stand
description: Colleen McCreary recently gave managers at Credit Karma a message that could seem more apt for rising sixth graders than personal finance executives.

title: One Mans Dream of Fusing A.I. With Common Sense
description: David Ferrucci, who led the team that built IBMs famed Watson computer, was elated when it beat the best-ever human Jeopardy! players in 2011, in a televised triumph for artificial intelligence.

title: Trying to Keep Americans Camping With Treehouses and Yurts
description: Some families plan annual summer trips in a quest to eventually visit every major-league ballpark across America. Over the past two years, Patty Lin Growden and her family have taken up a similar pursuit: campgrounds.

title: Referendum Seeks to Mend the Open Wound at Australias Heart
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  When Capt. James Cook sailed to Australia in 1768, he did so with instructions that he should show every kind of civility and regard to the lands Indigenous people and get their consent before possessing their land. He did neither.

title: Cloud Wars: Mideast Rivalries Rise Along a New Front
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Iranian officials have worried for years that other nations have been depriving them of one of their vital water sources. But it was not an upstream dam that they were worrying about, or an aquifer being bled dry.

title: Wood Is Life: A Hong Kong Sawmills Last Days
description: HONG KONG  From the brine-soaked docks of a ferry pier to the red-painted pillars of a Buddhist temple, many an aging wooden structure in Hong Kong has found new purpose in the hands of Wong Hung-kuen.

title: Well Teach Out of Anywhere: In Flooded Kentucky, Schools Race to Rebuild
description: COMBS, Ky.  Robin Combs has been teaching math for more than three decades, muscle memory guiding her as she reaches for the right lesson plans, confident in what works and how best to reach her middle school students. But when floodwaters surged through Robinson Elementary School last month, the roof collapsed on her classroom and three decades worth of curriculum materials were destroyed.

title: The Sunday Read: Shes at Brown. Her Hearts Still in Kabul.
description: Going to college can be a shock to most: Leaving the comfort of friends and family for a leap into the unknown, a fresh start. But what is the university experience like as a refugee?

title: Whats With All the Fluff About a New Civil War, Anyway?
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  The idea was to be permanently chastened by the Civil War, that the relief of emancipation and reunification would always be tempered by the shock of 600,000 corpses. And yet civil war has lately become one of those zeitgeist phrases that rattle around the internet, like quiet quitting or Pete Davidson.

title: Havent We Seen These Characters Before?
description: Summer has always loved a sequel. So why do this years comebacks and next chapters feel somehow worse? Not just mildly disappointing but also a little disquieting?

title: In Track and Field, Money Flows to the Flashy and Stylish
description: Raven Saunders watched Usain Bolts rise closely.

title: Ron DeSantiss Florida
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who appears to be preparing to run for president in 2024, has achieved a national platform by leaning into cultural battles. He signed laws limiting what teachers can teach about race, sexual orientation and gender identity, and he recently suspended an elected prosecutor who said he would refuse to enforce the states anti-abortion laws.

title: The Week in Business: Changing Consumer Habits
description: As consumers whims continue to evolve in the pandemic recovery, many companies that once enjoyed high-highs are feeling the sting of low-lows. That is especially true for the exercise bike company Peloton, which reported a $1.2 billion quarterly loss on Thursday  its sixth straight quarter of losses. After a pandemic boom, Peloton is now among the many retailers struggling to sell excess inventory. But its stationary bikes, priced at $1,445 and now available on Amazon, may still be a hard sell: Other earnings reports, like those from Dollar General and Dollar Tree this week, pointed to more cautious consumer spending. The two companies, the largest dollar-store chains in the country, posted higher sales and profits in their latest quarter as inflation eats into Americans budgets. In the past year, a majority of new customers shopping at Dollar Tree earned at least $80,000 annually, according to the companys chief executive  a sign that even higher earners are looking for bargains.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: There are many reasons to keep a block of silken tofu in your fridge at all times. Raw or steamed, whole or cubed, seasoned lightly or aggressively, silken tofu means dinner, fast.

title: Rick Reed, G.O.P. Adman of Swift Boat Campaign, Dies at 69
description: Rick Reed, a Republican advertising executive whose work in the 2004 presidential race tarnished Senator John Kerry, the Democratic nominee, by attacking his record as a Swift boat commander during the Vietnam War  giving rise to the term swift boating as a synonym for making ad hominem attacks, typically unfair, on a public figure  died on Aug. 17 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 69.

title: Why Pastors Are Burning Out
description: If you are part of a church, theres a good chance that your pastor is not all right.

title: Possible Scenarios to Deal With the Trump Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Bullying and Sex Abuse Scandal Engulfs Elite Danish School
description: Denmark, like most of Scandinavia, likes to see itself as a fair and equal society, with a nonhierarchical structure, high levels of happiness and trustworthy institutions dedicated to everyones well-being.

title: Over Caves and Over Budget, Mexicos Train Project Barrels Toward Disaster
description: PLAYA DEL CARMEN, Mexico  Twisted tree trunks were plowed into high piles along a slash of freshly cut jungle, like thousands of discarded matchsticks as far as the eye could see. This path of deforestation in southern Mexico was recently cleared to make way for an ambitious government project: the Maya Train railway.

title: Jaimie Branch, Trumpeter Who Crossed Genre Lines, Dies at 39
description: Jaimie Branch, an innovative avant-garde trumpet player and composer whose punk-rock intensity and commitment to experimentation and to dissolving the distinctions between genres invigorated the music scenes of New York and Chicago, died on Aug. 22 at her home in Red Hook, Brooklyn. She was 39.

title: Clashes Between Rival Militias in Libya Kill at Least 32
description: Some of the fiercest clashes in two years in Libyas capital between militias loyal to rival political leaders have left nearly three dozen people dead, as neighborhoods became battlefields and residents hunkered down in their homes, fearing a return to war in the country.

title: A Festival That Conjures the Magic of H.P. Lovecraft and Beyond
description: Theres bacon and eggs, and then theres bacon and eggs at the Cthulhu Prayer Breakfast. Named after the cosmically malevolent and abundantly tentacled entity dreamed up by Howard Phillips Lovecraft, the event, among the most popular at NecronomiCon Providence 2022, filled a vast hotel ballroom at 8 a.m. on a recent Sunday.

title: Central Mississippi Spared Feared Flooding From Heavy Rains, Officials Say
description: Shelters remained open on Monday as emergency crews assessed the impact of flooding on neighborhoods in central Mississippi, including in Jackson, an official said, after days of heavy rain had prompted the authorities to urge residents to evacuate over the weekend.

title: Biden Becomes a Boon for Democrats
description: The coattail effect in politics is the theory that the popularity of a candidate at the top of the ticket redounds to the benefit of those in the same party down ballot.

title: Devastating Floods in Pakistan Kill More Than a Thousand People
description: More than 33 million people have been affected by record rainfall this summer, according to Pakistans National Disaster Management Authority.

title: The MacGyvered Weapons in Ukraines Arsenal
description: WASHINGTON  The billions of dollars in military aid the United States has sent Ukraine includes some of the most advanced and lethal weapons systems in the world. But Ukraine has also scored big successes in the war by employing the weapons and equipment in unexpected ways, and jury-rigging some on the fly, according to military experts.

title: Leaving Los Angeles
description: It was early in the morning when I first ate toilet paper. My mother and my brother were still asleep. It tasted bad. I cried. I went for another bite. I needed the memory. I was 7 years old, and I knew I needed the memory.

title: American Real Estate Was a Money Launderers Dream. Thats Changing.
description: CLEVELAND  When a young man from Florida barely old enough to enter a bar began buying up office buildings in downtown Cleveland, many in the real estate industry here were eager to do business with him. Even though Chaim Schochet wasnt forthcoming about who his financial backers were or the particulars of his employer, Optima, he had deep pockets, and his company apparently was able to pay in cash.

title: Serena Williams Dominated Her Generation, Then the Next One, Too
description: Williams started her career as a teenager taking on seasoned veterans. She spent more than two decades fending off similar challenges from up-and-comers.

title: Baseball Card Sold for $12.6 Million, Breaking Record
description: A mint condition Mickey Mantle baseball card became the most valuable piece of sports memorabilia to be sold at auction, notching $12.6 million early Sunday morning.

title: Shelling Near Ukraine Nuclear Plant Strikes Towns, Heightening Concern
description: KYIV, Ukraine  For weeks, Russia and Ukraine have blamed each other for firing artillery at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in southern Ukraine, the largest power station in Europe, in a series of attacks that imperil not just the region, but also the whole world.

title: How and When to Watch NASAs Giant Rocket Launch to the Moon
description: Before NASA can send astronauts back to the moon, it needs a successful test flight of the Space Launch System, a giant rocket built for the agency with lunar missions in mind. On Monday, well get to see the first attempt at launching this massive rocket to orbit, this time with no astronauts aboard the Orion capsule it will send to space.

title: Your Monday Briefing: Record Heat Disrupts China
description: A record-setting drought and an 11-week heat wave are causing broad disruption in southwestern China, a region that depends on dams for more than three-quarters of its electricity generation.

title: Well, Look at That!
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Hello, solvers, and happy Monday! Todays puzzle was created by two veteran constructors, Jeff Chen and Chase Dittrich; this is their second collaboration, following an impressive Sunday puzzle from last year.

title: Republicans Signal Worries About Trump and the Midterms
description: WASHINGTON  Headed into 2022, Republicans were confident that a red wave would sweep them into control of Congress based on the conventional political wisdom that the midterm elections would produce a backlash against President Biden, who has struggled with low approval ratings.

title: A Triple-Bogey Start Vanquished, Rory McIlroy Captures the FedEx Cup
description: ATLANTA  On Thursday, his scorecard a shambles after only two holes at the Tour Championship, Rory McIlroy did not find himself thinking about golfs comeback magicians or his fellow major champions.

title: Trumps Legal Team Scrambles to Find an Argument
description: On May 25, one of former President Donald J. Trumps lawyers sent a letter to a top Justice Department official, laying out the argument that his client had done nothing illegal by holding onto a trove of government materials when he left the White House.

title: Inmate Who Was Pregnant Settles Suit Over Stop at Starbucks en Route to a Hospital
description: Sandra Quinones, six months pregnant, was at a jail in Orange County, Calif., when her water broke in March 2016, according to court records.

title: Beto ORourke Sidelined With Bacterial Infection Amid Texas Run
description: Beto ORourke, the former congressman and 2020 Democratic presidential candidate who is running to unseat Greg Abbott in the tightening race for Texas governor, said on Sunday that he would be sidelined from campaigning because of a bacterial infection.

title: House of the Dragon, Season 1, Episode 2: A Happy Announcement
description: A couple of centuries in Westeross future, in the same garden (I think) where King Viserys went on a blind date with a child on Sunday, Cersei Lannister will tell the soon-to-be-splooshed Oberyn Martell one of the saddest things anyone has ever heard.

title: Quotation of the Day: In Flood-Ravaged Kentucky, Schools Improvise in a Race to Reopen
description: I just want our kids back together and for eight hours a day, be normal  just normal. Theyre cool, theyve got a seat, theyve got food. I dont have to worry for eight hours a day.

title: No Corrections: Aug. 29, 2022
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: QAnon Accounts Found a Home, and Trumps Support, on Truth Social
description: Dozens of QAnon-boosting accounts decamped to Truth Social this year after they were banned by other social networks and have found support from the platforms creator, former President Donald J. Trump, according to a report released on Monday.

title: More Vital Than Ever, Ukraines Trains Bind a Land Fractured by War
